facts.text: Twenty-one writ petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution for writ of habeas corpus were filed.

anchor.surface_text: These twenty-one petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution for a writ of habeas companympus raise companymon questions of law and will be dealt with together.

facts.text: Petitioner in Writ Petition No. 142 of 1967 was arrested on November 11, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was arrested on November 11, 1966 and detained under an order passed under r. 30 1  b  of the Defence of India Rules, 1962  hereinafter referred to as the Rules .

facts.text: Petitioner detained under order passed under rule 30(1)(b) of the Defence of India Rules, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was arrested on November 11, 1966 and detained under an order passed under r. 30 1  b  of the Defence of India Rules, 1962  hereinafter referred to as the Rules .

facts.text: Detention order reviewed after six months without opportunity to represent to petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that though the order was reviewed after the period of six months, numberopportunity was given to the petitioner to represent his case before the reviewing authority.

facts.text: Detention became illegal after first six months per judgment in P.L. Lakhanpal v. Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence the detention of the petitioner be came illegal after the first period of six months in view of the judgment of this Court in P.L. Lakhanpal v. Union of India 1 .

facts.text: State Government cancelled detention order dated November 11, 1966 on August 3, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government realising this defect, cancelled the order dated November 11, 1966 on August 3, 1967, and on the same day a fresh order of detention was passed

facts.text: Fresh detention order passed on August 3, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government realising this defect, cancelled the order dated November 11, 1966 on August 3, 1967, and on the same day a fresh order of detention was passed and it is this order which

facts.text: It is not disputed that State Government could pass fresh detention order after revoking earlier one per Jadev Singh v. State of Jammu and Kashmir.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that in view of the judgment of this Court in Jadev Singh v. State of Jammu and Kashmir 1 , it was open to the State Government, in view of the formal defect in making the review,

facts.text: President passed order on November 3, 1962 under Article 359, amended on November 11, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The main attack of the petitioners is on the order of the President passed on November 3, 1962, as amended on November 11, 1962, under Art. 359 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: President's order suspended right to move court for enforcement of fundamental rights under Articles 14, 21 and 22 during Emergency.

anchor.surface_text: By this order the President declared that the right to move any companyrt for the enforcement of the fundamental rights companyferred by Arts. 14, 21 and 22 of the Constitution would remain suspended for the period during which the Proclamation of Emergency

facts.text: Proclamation of Emergency issued under Article 352.

anchor.surface_text: issued under Art. 352 1 , was in force, if any person was deprived of such right under the Defence of India Ordinance  No. 4 of 1962  or any rule or order made thereunder.

facts.text: Court finds no reason to disbelieve that fresh order was communicated.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberreason why the fresh order which was passed on the same day on which the earlier order was cancelled would number have been companymunicated.

facts.text: Article 166 of Constitution does not apply to State of Jammu and Kashmir.

anchor.surface_text: It is enough to say that Art. 166 does number apply to the State of Jammu and Kashmir.

facts.text: Fresh order in form required by section 45 of Constitution of Jammu and Kashmir.

anchor.surface_text: We have to look to the Constitution of Jammu and Kashmir to see whether the form of the order is in accordance therewith. It is clear that the order is in the form required by s. 45 of the Constitution of Jammu and Kashmir.

facts.text: Petitioners contend fresh orders were mala fide.

facts.text: State denies fresh orders were mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: It was finally denied that the order was mala fide in any of the cases.

facts.text: Court finds no grounds to conclude fresh orders mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: No grounds have been shown which may lead us to the companyclusion that the fresh orders which were passed were mala fide.

facts.text: Petitions dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petitions therefore fail and are hereby dismissed.

issues.text: Whether an order passed by the President under Art. 359 is a law within the meaning of Art. 13(2) and liable to be tested on the anvil of the fundamental rights enshrined in Part III of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: The argument in support is put this way. The President is an authority within the meaning of Art. 12 and therefore is companyprised within the definition of the word State and the order passed under Art. 359 is a law within the meaning of Art. 13 2  of the Constitution. Consequently an order passed by the President under Art. 359 is liable to be tested on the anvil of the fundamental rights enshrined in Part Ill of the Constitution

issues.text: Whether under Art. 359, enforcement of only those fundamental rights can be suspended which have nexus with the reasons for the Proclamation of Emergency, namely Arts. 22 and 31(2)?

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it is urged that an order passed under Art. 359 is made in the companytext of the Emergency and therefore enforcement of only such fundamental rights can be suspended which have nexus with the reasons which led to the Proclamation of Emergency. In companysequence, the President can only suspend the enforcement of fundamental rights under Art. 22 and Art. 31  2  under an order passed under Art. 359 and numberothers.

issues.text: Whether even if the President suspends enforcement of a fundamental right under Art. 359, the order can still be tested under that very fundamental right?

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, it is urged that even if the President can suspend the enforcement of any fundamental right, the order passed can still be tested under the very fundamental right enforcement of which has been suspended.

issues.text: Whether the order under Art. 359 is violative of Art. 14 due to discrimination between detentions under Defence of India Act/Rules and Preventive Detention Act?

anchor.surface_text: Fourthly, it is urged that an order passed under Art. 359 can in any case be challenged under Art. 14, and if so the order passed in the present case is violative of Art. 14 because some persons can be detained under the Defence of India Act, 51 of 1962  hereinafter referred to as the Act  and the Rules while others can be detained under the Preventive Detention Act.

issues.text: Whether, in view of the language of the order under Art. 359, there should have been an express provision in the Act and Rules suspending enforcement of Arts. 14, 21 and 22?

anchor.surface_text: Fifthly, it is urged that in view of the language of the order under Art. 359, there should have been an express provision in the Act and the Rules to the effect that enforcement of fundamental rights under Arts. 14, 21 and 22 was suspended and in the absence of such an express provision, the Presidential order under Art. 359 cannot stand in the way

issues.text: Whether Art. 22(5) requiring furnishing of grounds of detention continues to apply despite the Presidential order under Art. 359?

anchor.surface_text: Sixthly, it is urged that Art. 22  5   provides that grounds of detention should be furnished to a detenu and the order of the President did number do away with the necessity of furnishing the grounds.

issues.text: Whether the fresh order of detention had been communicated to the detenus?

anchor.surface_text: Besides these main companytentions, three subsidiary companytentions have also been raised in one petition or another and they are- 1  that the fresh order had number been companymunicated to the detenues and was therefore of numberavail

issues.text: Whether the fresh order of detention was in the form required by Art. 166 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: that the order was number in the form as required by Art. 166 of the Constitution and it is therefore for the State Government to prove that it was passed by the authority which had the power to do so

issues.text: Whether the fresh order of detention was mala fide?

issues.text: Whether an order under Art. 359 can be considered a law for the purpose of Art. 13(2) and tested thereunder?

anchor.surface_text: The question however is whether such an order can be companysidered to be a law for the purpose of Art. 13 2  and tested thereunder. Article 13 2  and Art. 359 being parts of the same Constitution stand on an equal footing and the two provisions have to be read harmoniously

arguments.claim: Order passed by President under Art.359 is a law within the meaning of Art.13(2) and liable to be tested under fundamental rights in Part III

anchor.surface_text: The argument in support is put this way. The President is an authority within the meaning of Art. 12 and therefore is comprised within the definition of the word State and the order passed under Art. 359 is a law within the meaning of Art. 13 2  of the Constitution. Consequently an order passed by the President under Art. 359 is liable to be tested on the anvil of the fundamental rights enshrined in Part Ill of the Constitution

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , for if that were so, Art. 359 would be made nugatory. The Constitution through Art. 359 says that the President may suspend the enforcement of any

arguments.court_reasoning: Art.13(2) and Art.359 read harmoniously; order cannot be considered law under Art.13(2) as it would render Art.359 nugatory

arguments.claim: Under Art.359, only fundamental rights with nexus to reasons for Emergency (Art.22 and Art.31(2)) can be suspended

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it is urged that an order passed under Art. 359 is made in the context of the Emergency and therefore enforcement of only such fundamental rights can be suspended which have nexus with the reasons which led to the Proclamation of Emergency. In consequence, the President can only suspend the enforcement of fundamental rights under Art. 22 and Art. 31  2  under an order passed under Art. 359 and noothers.

arguments.court_reasoning: Art.359 gives categorical power to suspend any fundamental right; no nexus inquiry needed as suspension is for security of India

arguments.claim: Even if President suspends enforcement of fundamental right under Art.359, the order can still be tested under that right

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, it is urged that even if the President can suspend the enforcement of any fundamental right, the order passed can still be tested under the very fundamental right enforcement of which has been suspended.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a particular fundamental right suspended and the security of India. Article 359 itself posits that it may be necessary in the interest of the security

arguments.court_reasoning: Testing order under suspended right would argue in circle and render Art.359 nugatory

arguments.court_reasoning: No grounds shown for mala fides

arguments.claim: Art.359 gives President categorical power to suspend enforcement of any fundamental rights in Part III during Emergency; no limitation or distinction between rights

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen from the terms or Art. 359 that it gives categorical powers to the President during the period when a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation to suspend the enforcement of any of the fundamental rights conferred by Part III.

arguments.claim: Art.13(2) and Art.359 must be read harmoniously; order under 359 not 'law' under 13(2)

anchor.surface_text: Article 13 2  and Art. 359 being parts of the same Constitution stand on an equal footing and the two provisions have to be read harmoniously

arguments.claim: Order under Art.359 cannot be tested under suspended fundamental right as it would render Art.359 nugatory

anchor.surface_text: If the order is a law within the meaning of Art. 13 2 , the result would be that though the order says that the enforcement of a particular fundamental right is suspended during the period of Emergency the order can still be tested with the aid of Art. 13 2  on the anvil of the same fundamental right, the enforcement of which it suspends. That would in our opinion result in making Art. 359 completely nugatory

arguments.claim: View in Ghulam Sarwar that Art.359 order testable under suspended Art.14 is incorrect; respectfully differ

anchor.surface_text: We must therefore respectfully differ from the view taken in Ghulam Sarwars case 1  and hold that an order passed under Art. 359 1  cannot be tested with the aid of Art. 13 2  under that very fundamental right the enforcement of which it suspends.

arguments.claim: No nexus required between suspended right and security of India; Art.359 posits suspension for security

anchor.surface_text: There is no scope for inquiry into the question whether the fundamental right the enforcement of which the President has suspended under Art. 359 has anything to do with the security of India which is threatened whether by war or external aggression or internal disturbance, for Art. 359 posits that it may be necessary for the President to suspend any of the fundamental rights in Part HI for the sake of the security of India.

arguments.claim: Suspension under Art.359 applies to entire Art.22, including clause (5)

anchor.surface_text: If the Presidents order is validly made-as we hold it to be-and if it suspends Art. 22--as it does--we fail to see how clause  5   continues, for it is only a part of Art. 22 which has been suspended.

arguments.claim: In Ghulam Sarwar, order upheld as applicable to class (foreigners) in emergency; room left for Art.14 in cases of mala fide or abuse

anchor.surface_text: Room was, however, to be left for the play of Art. 14 for those theoretically possible  and fortunately only theoretically possible  cases in which the exercise of the power itself may be a cloak for discrimination, in other words, cases of mala fide action and clear abuse of the power for some collateral purpose.

holdings.text: An order passed under Article 359 cannot be considered a law within the meaning of Article 13(2) and cannot be tested under the fundamental rights whose enforcement it suspends.

anchor.surface_text: Article 13 2  and Art. 359 being parts of the same Constitution stand on an equal footing and the two provisions have to be read harmoniously in order that the intention behind Art. 359 is carried out and it is not destroyed altogether by Art. 13 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of Art.13(2) and Art.359; testing order under suspended right would render Art.359 nugatory; respectfully differs from Ghulam Sarwar.

holdings.text: Article 359 gives the President categorical power to suspend enforcement of any fundamental right in Part III during Emergency without requiring nexus to security of India.

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen from the terms or Art. 359 that it gives categorical powers to the President during the period when a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation to suspend the enforcement of any of the fundamental rights conferred by Part III.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Art.359; posits suspension for security of India without further inquiry.

holdings.text: Once enforcement of a fundamental right is suspended under Article 359, no order or action cannot be tested under that suspended right.

anchor.surface_text: the contention on behalf of the State is that once the President has passed an order under Art. 359 suspending the enforcement of any fundamental right, it is not open to rely on that fundamental right for any purpose

holdings.reasoning_summary: Would argue in circle and make Art.359 nugatory; accepts State's contention.

holdings.text: Presidential order under Article 359 not violative of Article 14 as its enforcement is suspended.

anchor.surface_text: As the enforcement of the fundamental right under Art. 14 was suspended by the Presidents order under Art. 359, no question of that order being bad under that Article can arise even if we assume that the provisions for detention under the Act and the Rules are more stringent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enforcement of Art.14 suspended; cannot challenge under it.

holdings.text: No express provision required in Defence of India Act or Rules to suspend enforcement of Articles 14, 21, 22; Presidential order directly applies.

anchor.surface_text: it was not necessary that there should be any express provision in the Act or the Rules suspending the enforcement of fundamental rights under Arts. 14,21 and 22. The clear intendment of the Presidents order is that if any fundamental right [...] was invaded by any action taken under the Ordinance [...] that action could not be tested

holdings.reasoning_summary: Such provision would be unconstitutional; Art.359 order suspends for deprivations under those laws.

holdings.text: Article 22(5) does not apply as entire Article 22 is suspended by Presidential order under Article 359.

anchor.surface_text: If the Presidents order is validly made-as we hold it to be-and if it suspends Art. 22--as it does--we fail to see how clause 5 continues, for it is only a part of Art. 22 which has been suspended.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suspension covers entire Art.22; clause (5) is part thereof.

holdings.text: Fresh detention order was communicated to the detenus.

anchor.surface_text: We see no reason why the fresh order which was passed on the same day on which the earlier order was cancelled would not have been communicated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reason to disbelieve State's denial; passed same day as cancellation.

holdings.text: Article 166 does not apply to Jammu & Kashmir; fresh order in form required by s.45 of J&K Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is enough to say that Art. 166 does not apply to the State of Jammu and Kashmir. We have to look to the Constitution of Jammu and Kashmir to see whether the form of the order is in accordance therewith. It is clear that the order is in the form required by s. 45 of the Constitution of Jammu and Kashmir.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.166 inapplicable; complies with J&K Const.; presumption of validity.

holdings.text: Fresh detention orders were not mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: No grounds have been shown which may lead us to the conclusion that the fresh orders which were passed were mala fide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No grounds shown; necessitated by defect in review per precedent.

holdings.text: The writ petitions fail and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The petitions therefore fail and are hereby dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; detentions valid under circumstances.
